channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Britain’s Drift From the Global Stage Becomes an Election Issue
item.description: On matters like Ukraine and the Middle East, even its alliance with the United States, Britain is ceding its reputation for “punching above its weight.”
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Japan and U.S. Set New Rules for Military Cooperation
item.description: The new guidelines, which envision an expanded role for Japanese forces, were announced a day before Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was to visit the White House.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Piecing Together a Deadly Encounter in Paris
item.description: The killing of a fitness instructor in what appeared to be a chance encounter has left the French authorities scrambling to unravel the plans a terrorism suspect.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Raymond Truy/Mairie De Caudry, via European Pressphoto Agency

item.title: Climbers Describe Havoc on Mount Everest After Nepal Earthquake
item.description: As rescue efforts were hampered by bad weather, dramatic details emerged about the devastation at the base camp in the wake of an avalanche.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Critically injured people being evacuated from Everest Base Camp in Nepal on Sunday.

item.title: U.N. Says Israeli Military Actions Killed 44 Civilians in Schools in Gaza War
item.description: The internal inquiry is the first United Nations report to come out of the 50-day conflict last summer between Israeli forces and Hamas militants.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Villages Near Nepal Earthquake’s Epicenter Are Desperate as Death Toll Tops 3,800
item.description: Residents of Gorkha district say houses collapsed, food is running out and so far no one has arrived with aid.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Greece Says It Is Changing Team That Negotiates With Creditors
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is putting officials in charge of day-to-day talks who are less polarizing than the finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Yanis Varoufakis, front, the Greek finance minister, and Euclid Tsakalotos, a deputy foreign minister, after a meeting with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Athens this month.

item.title: Google and Facebook Help Nepal Earthquake Survivors and Contacts Connect
item.description: As the extent of the damage became clear, the companies devised ways to help users in affected areas connect with friends and loved ones, and vice versa.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Migrants, Hoping to Cross Mediterranean, Must First Navigate a Lawless Libya
item.description: Despite the costs and risks, migrants continue to traverse a country where warring militias have become the only law.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: From left, Efrem Fitwi, Hermon Angosam and Filimon Burust joined the unceasing flow of Arab and African migrants who are churned through the lawlessness of post-Qaddafi Libya.

item.title: Open Source: British Conservatives Suspend Candidate for Anti-Semitic Facebook Slur
item.description: The candidate, Gulzabeen Afsar, suggested that the leader of the opposition Labour Party, Ed Miliband, was unfit to succeed the leader of her party.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: You Are What You Burn
item.description: Honoring the dead with paper goods remains a common ritual in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: NURY VITTACHI

item.title: President of Sudan Is Re-elected With 94 Percent of Vote
item.description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan won a race that was boycotted by the opposition and marred by low voter turnout.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan during an election campaign in March in Khartoum. He has been re-elected, the Sudanese Elections Committee said on Monday.

item.title: China Opens Corruption Inquiry Into Sinopec President
item.description: The move means Wang Tianpu will almost certainly be removed from his job soon and purged from the Communist Party after being accused of corruption.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Wang Tianpu, president of Sinopec, is being investigated for “serious violations” of laws and discipline.

item.title: Kazakhstan’s President Is Re-elected by Almost Every Voter
item.description: Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, who has governed the country since the Soviet Union collapsed, secured his fifth term with 97.7 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Iranian General Says Saudi Arabia Will Soon Be Toppled
item.description: Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, the head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, predicted that the Saudi campaign in Yemen would backfire.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, the head of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, in Tehran in 2011.

item.title: Brazil’s Power Dynamics Shifting Amid Political Scandals
item.description: Despite have faced corruption accusations themselves, the men who command Brazil’s scandal-plagued Congress are actually increasing their power over the scandal-plagued president, Dilma Rousseff.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: The head of the Senate, Renan Calheiros, far left, with the speaker of the lower house of Congress, Eduardo Cunha. Both have faced corruption accusations but have increased their power against President Dilma Rousseff as Brazilians fume about the economy and a bribery case at the national oil company.

item.title: South Korea’s Premier Resigns After Claims He Took an Illegal Cash Gift
item.description: Lee Wan-koo, the second prime minister to step down under President Park Geun-hye, denied that he had received the money, but calls mounted for his resignation.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo of South Korea during his departure ceremony on Monday in the capital, Seoul.

item.title: Chinese Officers Harshly Interrogated Women’s Rights Activist, Husband Says
item.description: The account showed the continued official pressure on five women who had been detained, despite their release from jail this month.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Details Emerge of China-Financed Dam Project in Pakistan
item.description: A modest-size dam on the Jhelum River at a site 35 miles east of the Pakistani capital, Islamabad, will be the first project financed by China’s $40 billion Silk Road Fund.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:credit: Press Information Department, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China flanked by the Pakistani president, Mamnoon Hussain, left, and prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, on Mr. Xi’s arrival in Islamabad on April 20.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Keeping Count: Corrupt Chinese Officials and Their Mistresses
item.description: Though not a criminal offense in China, adultery is a violation of Communist Party rules. Here is a look at six former officials who were brought down on corruption charges and have been accused of having mistresses.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MIA LI
item.media:description: The east gate of the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, the gathering place for top government and Communist Party officials.
